questions.text: The given incision can be used in the surgery of which of the following conditions.
questions.solution:
The image shows Moure's incision also called lateral rhinotomy which is used for the surgical removal of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. 

A medial maxillectomy involves resectioning the entire lateral wall of the nasal cavity, the ethmoid sinuses, and the medial part of the orbital floor. This is done for invasive tumors of the nasal cavity including angiofibroma and inverted papilloma. 

Indications of a lateral rhinotomy :

  • Inverted papilloma
  • Juvenile Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
  • Septal perforation repair
  • Medial maxillectomy

Other options:

Option A: In cases of anterosuperior epistaxis above the middle turbinate, ligation of the anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries that supply this area may be necessary, if packing is ineffective. Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision.

Option B: The image shows Weber Ferugson's incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma to perform median maxillectomy. A median maxillectomy involves surgical resection of the medial and superomedial walls of the maxillary antrum done for maxillary carcinoma. 

Option C : Killian’s incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2–3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum. Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incision taken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken which is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about the diagnosis?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice
Carotid angiography is the investigation of choice
Radiation is done in case of intracranial extension
Blood supply is from the internal maxillary artery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a 16-year-old boy presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year and a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) scan showing anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign) is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. CECT is the investigation of choice for this condition, not carotid angiography.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males aged 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity, close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that grows to form angiofibroma under the influence of testosterone. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Blood supply is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis - most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech - due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion - due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions.

Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels also come from the internal carotid system. 

 Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign; may occur along with the erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered. Radiation can be used in cases of intracranial extension.

questions.text: A 19-year-old drummer presented with complaints of difficulty in hearing and severe pain in the left ear. Otoscopic examination revealed impacted wax with pearly white keratinous debris in the external auditory canal. Audiometry revealed a conductive hearing loss. Which of the following complications is least likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Exposure and damage to the facial nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, with pearly white keratin debris in the external auditory canal, suggests the diagnosis of keratosis obturans. Narrowing of the meatus is the least likely complication, as this condition is associated with widening of the meatus.

Due to the pressure effect by desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus, there is subsequent absorption of surrounding bone, leading to the widening of the meatus. Sometimes, the extent of bone absorption is such that it leaves the facial nerve exposed to injury and subsequent paralysis. Extensive erosion of the bone can also result in automastoidectomy.

Keratosis obturans is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Conventionally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of or any obstruction to this migration caused by wax impacted in the ear canal may lead to keratosis obturans.

It is usually seen between the ages of 5-20 years and is commonly unilateral. Clinical features include severe otalgia and difficulty in hearing. It is associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. 

On otoscopic examination, there is a thickening of the tympanic membrane and a keratin plug appearing like a pearly white mass occluding the canal. The keratin that is shed from the entire circumference of the deep ear canal appears to have an onion skin arrangement. There is also hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulations. 

Treatment involves the removal of the plug by syringing or instrumentation. Any recurrence can be prevented with the use of keratolytics such as 2% salicylic acid in alcohol.

Note: Narrowing refers to a decrease in the diameter of the meatus. Debris in kerotosis obturans or ear wax might cause obstruction (partial or complete) but does not cause narrowing. Narrowing of the meatus is seen in conditions such as ear canal stenosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a three-month history of ear pain. He has been chewing tobacco for 40 years. During a comprehensive examination, an ulcerative lesion is discovered on the vallecula. Which nerve is responsible for the patient’s ear pain?
questions.solution:
The patient with an ulcerative lesion on the vallecula has ear pain likely referred by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve.

Referred ear pain can occur when a lesion or pathology exists in an area supplied by the vagus nerve, such as the vallecula. The history of tobacco use and the presence of an ulcerative lesion strongly suggest malignancy, which is known to cause referred pain.

Referred otalgia can arise from various sources, including dental issues, temporomandibular joint disorders, and pathologies involving the throat, base of the tongue, and upper digestive tract. The vagus nerve and other cranial nerves like the glossopharyngeal (IX) and trigeminal (V) play a significant role in transmitting pain signals from these areas to the ear.

Referred otalgia is mediated by the following nerves:

Auriculotemporal branch of the trigeminal nerve (V nerve):

  • Dental - impacted teeth, caries, Costen syndrome
  • Oral cavity - ulcerative or benign lesions of tongue and oral mucosa
  • Temporomandibular joint - osteoarthritis, bruxism, dislocation, dentures
  • Sphenopalatine neuralgia

Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (IX nerve):

  • Oropharynx - lesions of the palate, and tonsil including the tonsillar pillars
  • The base of tongue - tuberculosis or malignancy
  • Eagle's syndrome - elongated styloid process

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (X nerve):

  • Lesions of esophagus
  • Lesions of larynx
  • Vallecula
  • Epiglottis

Greater auricular nerve (C2, C3 nerve)/Lesser occipital nerve (C2 nerve):

  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Caries spine
  • Spinal lesions

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, stridor, drooling, and muffled voice. The following image is seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck. What is the finding seen in the given radiograph?
questions.solution:
Thumb sign is seen on the given lateral view radiograph.

The above clinical features of a toxic looking child with high-grade fever, tachypnea, stridor, dysphagia with salivary drooling are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. Thumb sign on lateral X-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive confined to supraglottic structures i.e., epiglottis, aryepiglottic fold and arytenoids. It usually affects children of age 2-7 years. It has a potentially fulminating course of fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Management:

Indirect laryngoscopy shows edema and congestion of supraglottic structures. A lateral X-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis giving an appearance called the thumb sign.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to ICU
  • Airway management - endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy for respiratory obstruction
  • Antibiotics - Ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporin is indicated in the treatment of acute epiglottitis along with airway management.
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema

Other options:

Option A: Steeple sign is seen in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Option C- Below image shows adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D- Omega shaped epiglottis is seen in laryngomalacia. This finding is seen in direct laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 60-year-old singer visited ENT surgeon with the complaints of change of voice for the past few months. After a thorough examination, the doctor explained the reason for voice change is the laxity of the vocal cord due to the aging process. What type of thyroplasty can be performed in this person to improve his voice?
questions.solution:
Type 4 thyroplasty is performed to improve the voice in the above clinical scenario.

Type IV thyroplasty is used to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cord and elevate the pitch. It is used when vocal cord is lax and bowing due to aging process or trauma.

It is used to convert the male character of voice to female and has been used in gender transformation.

Thyroplasty is a phonosurgical technique which aims to improve the voice by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

  • Type I: Medialization of vocal cord
  • Type II: Lateralization of vocal cord
  • Type III: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
  • Type IV: Lengthening or tightening of the vocal cord

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer who spends most of his time working in the rice field presented with nasal obstruction. Rhinoscopic examination revealed a pink polypoidal mass in his left nostril. Histopathologic examination showed several sporangia with a thick wall, filled with spores. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the histopathology findings are suggestive of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • Chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • Most prevalent in rural districts, among persons bathing in public ponds or working in stagnant water, such as rice fields. 
  • Most common in persons in the age range of 15–40; males are more commonly affected than females.
  • The rhinoscopic examination will reveal papular or nodular, smooth-surfaced lesions that become pedunculated and acquire a papillomatous or proliferative appearance. The lesions are pink, red or purple in colour
  • Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores.
  • The treatment of choice is surgical excision of lesions, with or without cauterization.

Note: Not many drugs are effective against this disease. Dapsone has been tried with some success.

questions.text: A boy diagnosed with acute otitis media 1 week back, presents with fever, post-auricular pain (image shown), and purulent discharge from his ear. There is mastoid tenderness and the meatus immediately fills with pus when it's cleaned. What is the definitive management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The definitive management of this child who presented with acute mastoiditis and has a positive reservoir sign is a cortical mastoidectomy.

Mastoiditis involves inflammation and infection of the mastoid air cells and often follows acute otitis media. It is characterized by symptoms such as fever, postauricular pain and tenderness, swelling, and ear discharge. A diagnosis can be made through clinical examination, imaging studies like CT scans, and culture of ear discharge to identify causative organisms.

Initial treatment includes antibiotics, but when these and other conservative measures fail, and symptoms persist or worsen, surgical intervention is necessary to prevent further complications such as subperiosteal abscesses, facial nerve paralysis, and intracranial spread. A cortical mastoidectomy, which involves removing the infected air cells within the mastoid bone, draining abscesses, and ensuring adequate aeration of the mastoid cavity, is often the first surgical step aimed at eradicating infection and preventing further complications. 

Indications for Cortical Mastoidectomy:

  • Presence of a subperiosteal abscess
  • Sagging of the posterosuperior meatal wall
  • Positive reservoir sign (meatus immediately fills with pus after it has been mopped out)
  • Lack of improvement or worsening of symptoms despite adequate antibiotic treatment for 48 hours
  • Development of complications from mastoiditis, such as:
  • Facial paralysis
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Intracranial complications (e.g., meningitis, brain abscess)

Other Options:

Option B: While IV antibiotics are initially used, the severity and persistence of symptoms in this case require surgical intervention to prevent further complications.

Option C: Myringotomy involves creating an incision in the tympanic membrane to drain middle ear fluid. It is a less invasive procedure often used in early or uncomplicated cases but insufficient for advanced mastoiditis.

Option D: Radical mastoidectomy is a more extensive procedure involving the removal of more structures within the mastoid and middle ear. It is typically reserved for chronic or recurrent cases where less invasive surgeries have failed.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old race car champion is brought by his manager to the ENT surgeon for the correction of the condition shown below, which occurred after sustaining a blow to the face by the runner-up two months prior. The driver is asymptomatic and is scheduled to undergo an SMR operation. Identify the false statement about this procedure.

SMR - Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum

choices.text: Re-operating is easier compared to septoplasty
Not done before the age of 17 years
Periosteal flaps raised on both sides of septum
Greater chance of complications compared to septoplasty

questions.solution:
The false statement about the SMR (Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum) is option 1. Re-operating following an SMR is difficult compared to a septoplasty, which involves fewer complications and an easier re-operation.

The given clinical vignette with an image showing the midline of the dorsum of the nose deviated to one side is indicative of a deviated nasal septum.

Deviated nasal septum (DNS) is an important cause of nasal obstruction. It is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Headache
  • Epistaxis
  • Anosmia
  • External deformity. 

The indications for an SMR are:

  • DNS causing symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches.
  • DNS causing obstruction of paranasal sinuses and middle ear, resulting in recurrent sinusitis and otitis media.
  • Recurrent epistaxis from a septal spur.
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty, for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities.
  • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy or vidian neurectomy.

It is contraindicated in children below 17 years of age, during acute respiratory infection, bleeding diathesis, untreated diabetes, or hypertension.

In this procedure, mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps are raised on both sides of the septum. Bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum are excised. This is followed by extensive dissection of the septum removing all deformed bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum and preserving only a caudal and a dorsal strut of cartilage.

There is a greater chance of complications associated with SMR that include bleeding, septal hematoma, septal abscess, perforation, depression of nasal bridge, retraction of columella and persistence of the deviation. Flapping of nasal septum and toxic shock syndrome following SMR can also occur.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed to have a mass in his fossa of Rosenmuller which had keratinising squamous epithelium on biopsy. It is found to be stage II. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The treatment of choice for stage II is radiotherapy.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy. 

Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone. 

Stage III and IV are treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can be neoadjuvant, concurrent, or adjuvant to radiotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Asch's forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum.

Walsham and Asch’s forceps are used to reduce nasal bone fractures.

  • Walsham is mainly used to reduce the bone fracture.
  • Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum.

Tilly's forceps is used for insertion or removal of nasal packing or dressings.

Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of a rapidly progressing infection in the floor of the mouth, characterized by swelling, severe pain, difficulty swallowing, and elevation of the tongue. He is diagnosed with Ludwig's angina. Which of the following spaces is not typically involved as a primary space in his condition?
questions.solution:
Ludwig's angina is a severe, rapidly progressing cellulitis that affects the floor of the mouth and the submandibular region, which primarily involves sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces, while the masseteric space is a secondary space. 

Primary Spaces Involved in Ludwig's Angina:

  • Sublingual Space:
    - Location: Above the mylohyoid muscle and underneath the oral mucosa.
    - Causes of Infection: Dental infections (premolars and first molar), penetrating injuries (fish bones, wood splinters), and anesthetic injections.
    - Symptoms: Swelling, pain, elevation of the floor of the mouth.
  • Submandibular Space:
    - Location: Below the mylohyoid muscle, between it and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia.
    - Contents: Submandibular salivary gland and lymph nodes.
    - Communication: Connects with sublingual and submental spaces.
    - Causes of Infection: Dental infections (second and third molars), submandibular sialadenitis, lymph node suppuration.
    - Symptoms: Swelling, tenderness, possible fever, difficulty swallowing.
  • Submental Space:
    - Location: Between the symphysis of the mandible anteriorly, the hyoid bone below, and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle laterally.
    - Floor: Mylohyoid muscle.
    - Boundaries: Inferiorly bounded by a superficial layer of deep cervical fascia.
    - Spread of Infection: From the submandibular space, it can cross the midline to contralateral submental and sublingual spaces.
    - Symptoms: Swelling, pain, potential airway compromise.

Secondary Spaces: The secondary spaces, collectively known as the masticator space, are around the muscles of mastication:

  • Masseteric Space:
    - Location: Around the masseter muscle.
    - Involvement: Secondary to infections from primary spaces or third molar.
    - Symptoms: Marked trismus (difficulty opening the mouth).
  • Pterygomandibular Space:
    - Location: Between the medial pterygoid muscle and the mandible.
    - Involvement: Secondary to spreading infections.
    - Symptoms: Swelling, pain, trismus.
  • Temporal Space:
    - Location: Around the temporalis muscle.
    - Involvement: Secondary to posteriorly spreading infections.
    - Symptoms: Pain, and swelling in the temporal region.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress. After the initial assessment, the decision is made to perform an emergency tracheostomy. Which of the following steps prevents the formation of subcutaneous emphysema during the procedure?

choices.text: Vertical midline incision from cricoid cartilage to sternal notch
Inserting tracheostomy tube of appropriate size
Avoiding tight suturing of skin incision

questions.solution:
In a tracheostomy procedure, the skin incision should not be sutured or packed tightly. Tightly suturing the skin can lead to the development of subcutaneous emphysema, a condition where air becomes trapped under the skin.

Subcutaneous emphysema can cause swelling, and discomfort, and may even extend to the chest and neck, potentially compromising the airway further. Instead of suturing tightly, a gauze dressing is placed between the skin and the flange of the tracheostomy tube around the stoma. This dressing allows air to escape, reducing the risk of subcutaneous emphysema. It also helps to absorb any secretions and provides a barrier to infection, promoting proper healing. 

Steps of Tracheostomy:

  • Incision: Make a vertical incision in the midline from the cricoid cartilage to above the sternal notch. For elective procedures, a 5 cm transverse incision two fingers' breadth above the sternal notch can be used for a better cosmetic outcome.
  • Dissection: Dissect tissues in the midline. Displace or ligate any dilated veins encountered to control bleeding.
  • Muscle Separation: Separate and retract the strap muscles of the neck laterally to expose underlying structures.
  • Thyroid Isthmus Management: Displace the thyroid isthmus upwards or divide and ligate it with sutures.
  • Local Anesthesia: Inject a few drops of 4% lignocaine into the trachea to suppress coughing.
  • Tracheal Incision: Fix the trachea with a hook and make a vertical incision between the third and fourth tracheal rings, converting it into a circular opening. Avoid dividing the first tracheal ring to prevent perichondritis and stenosis.
  • Inserting the Tube: Insert a tracheostomy tube of appropriate size into the tracheal opening and secure it with tapes.
  • Avoiding Tight Suturing: Avoid tightly suturing or packing the skin incision to prevent subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Dressing: Place a gauze dressing between the skin and the flange of the tracheostomy tube around the stoma to absorb secretions, provide a barrier against infection, and allow air to escape, promoting proper healing

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to you with impaction of the fishbone in the area which forms the lateral channel for food. All of the following form the boundaries of this area except?
questions.solution:
The given scenario represents the impaction of fishbone in the pyriform fossa, which forms the lateral channel for food. The pyriform fossa is not bounded medially by the cuneiform cartilage.

Pyriform fossa:

It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It is bounded laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, posterolateral surfaces of arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. 

The internal laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and this is easily accessible for local anesthesia. It is also through this nerve that the pain is referred to as the ear in the carcinoma of the pyriform sinus.

Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of lymph nodes. The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

CN V - Cranial nerve V

choices.text: Most common site of origin is the fossa of Rosenmuller
CN V involvement leads to reduced corneal reflex
Hearing loss is the most common presentation
Tumor can invade the orbit and cause exophthalmos

questions.solution:
The statement ‘hearing loss is the most common presentation’ is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller (Option A). From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
    • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Diagnosis is made by high resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck.

The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following marked blood vessels is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery which is represented by the marked blood vessel "3" in the given image.

Other blood vessels marked in the image are 

1 - Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery

2 - Tonsillar branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery

4 - Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: The lateral view neck x-ray of a 65-year-old male patient showed the presence of a foreign body in the larynx. You suspect that it may represent calcification of one of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of the following cartilages is most likely to undergo calcification mimicking the laryngeal foreign body?
questions.solution:
The cricoid cartilage undergoes calcification, which may mimic a foreign body on x-ray.

Only hyaline cartilage can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It mostly is seen at the age of 25–65 years. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of the esophagus or larynx on x-rays.

Hyaline laryngeal cartilages:

  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Most of the arytenoid cartilage

Elastic laryngeal cartilages:

  • Epiglottic cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Tip of the arytenoid cartilage

questions.text: A girl presents with intractable bleeding from the nose. She had tried the technique shown below on her family doctor's advice, but the bleeding did not stop. Which of the following is correct regarding the next best step?

choices.text: Topical antibiotics are indicated if the pack is not removed in 24 hours
Intermittent oxygen may be required in patients with either left or right sided nasal pack
Merocel is used as a first-line agent for nasal packing
Patients requiring postnasal pack do not require hospitalization

questions.solution:
Merocel is used as a first-line agent for nasal packing, which is the next best step after trying Trotter’s method which is shown in the image.

Here, the patient leans forward in the sitting position, over a basin, and spits any blood oozing into the mouth while breathing through it. Merocel is a non-absorbable nasal packing material that increases in size on rehydration with normal saline. This compresses the bleeding vessel.

Epistaxis is bleeding from inside the nose and is commonly seen in all age groups. It can be due to trauma, infections, foreign bodies, or local neoplasms. Some systemic conditions like thrombocytopenia, liver diseases, and hemophilia can result in the condition.

Management of Epistaxis:

  1. Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.
  2. Cauterisation of the bleeding point with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.
  3. Anterior nasal packing.
  4. Posterior nasal packing for which patients should be hospitalized.
  5. Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 
  6. Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.
  7. Ligation of vessels.
  8. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia. It is effective in controlling refractory posterior bleeds.
  9. Embolization of the internal maxillary artery by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization. 

The image below depicts nasal packing.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic and not topical antibiotics are indicated if the nasal pack is planned to stay for 2-3 days. It prevents sinus infections and toxic shock syndrome.

Option B: Intermittent oxygen may be required in patients with bilateral nasal packs and not unilateral because of increased pulmonary resistance from naso-pulmonary reflex.

Option D: Patients requiring postnasal packs should always be hospitalized. It is important to evaluate the cause of epistaxis.

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure a person is positioned as shown in the image given below. Which key structure(s) that would be visualized best with this view?

questions.solution:

questions.text: A  woman with a history of hearing loss undergoes hearing tests using tuning forks. She continues to hear the sound near her ear after the tuning fork is moved from the mastoid, in both ears. When the tuning fork is placed on her forehead she hears the sound better on the right side. These findings are consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has a positive Rinne test and a Weber test that lateralizes to the right, indicating left-sided sensorineural hearing loss. The most appropriate option is a left acoustic neuroma.

An acoustic neuroma can exert a mass effect on the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) and cause unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, typically presenting as a progressive hearing loss with possible tinnitus and balance issues. 

Hearing tests, such as the Rinne and Weber tests, are essential tools in differentiating between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. The Rinne test involves placing a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid bone and then near the ear canal. A positive Rinne test, where air conduction is better than bone conduction, indicates normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss. A negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is better than air conduction, indicates conductive hearing loss.

 The Weber test involves placing a vibrating tuning fork on the forehead. If the sound lateralizes to one side, it can indicate either conductive hearing loss in that ear or sensorineural hearing loss in the opposite ear. These tests help diagnose the underlying cause of hearing loss and determine the appropriate treatment.

Option A: Cholesteatoma causes conductive hearing loss due to erosion of the ossicles. A symptomatic cholesteatoma on the right would result in a negative Rinne test on the right and the Weber test lateralizing to the right.

Option C: Cochlear damage causes sensorineural hearing loss, with the Weber test lateralizing to the unaffected side (left). Since the Weber test lateralized to the right, cochlear damage on the right is not consistent with the findings.

Option D: Otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss, typically resulting in a negative Rinne test on the affected side (left) and the Weber test lateralizing to the same side. The patient's positive Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the right do not match otosclerosis on the left.

questions.text:
Match the following:

a. Le-Fort type 1
b. Le-Fort type 3
c. Le-Fort type 2
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: a-1, b-3, c-2.

Le-Fort’s types are used in the classification of maxillary fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment for Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Vidian neurectomy is not a treatment for Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). It is a treatment option for crocodile tears (gustatory lacrimation).

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) 

There are sweating and flushing of skin over the parotid area during mastication. It is a complication of parotid surgery. It results due to aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve (which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands.

Management options:

  • Use of antiperspirants
  • Subcutaneous injection of purified botulinum toxin
  • Auriculotemporal nerve avulsion 
  • Denervation by tympanic neurectomy

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with a suspected tumour in the nasopharynx. This tumor is associated with Ebstein Barr virus infections. What is the most common site of this tumor?
questions.solution:
This patient with a tumour in the nasopharynx and association with the Ebstein Barr virus most likely has nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Fossa of Rossenmuller is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types - keratinizing carcinoma, nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma and nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes.

Diagnosis is made by high resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck. The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following devices is best used in the management of otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Device 3 is a picture of a piston, used in patients with otosclerosis. 

The treatment of choice for otosclerosis is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis (piston). The Teflon piston is a frequently used prosthesis in stapes surgery. To position the Teflon loop, it is initially spread out on the shaft of a needle perforator and then placed on the incus. Once in position, it encircles the long process of the incus and closes around it.

The given images are:

  1. Bone Anchored Hearing Aid
  2. Cochlear implant
  3. Stapedectomy piston
  4. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia and conductive deafness not amenable to other treatment procedures. Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA. It is comprised of a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear, which allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear. This process is known as direct bone conduction. 

Device 2 is a picture of a cochlear implant. It is an electronic device used in patients with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It works by directly stimulating the auditory nerve and bypassing the cochlear hair cells that are damaged. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve. The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis (PORP) that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes are structurally intact and mobile. PORP is placed between the tympanic membrane and the stapes head.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A middle-aged woman, who had undergone a polypectomy complains of watery nasal discharge on bending forward. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery.

Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea:
1. The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance.
2. It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D)
3. It does not stiffen a handkerchief.
4. It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in drops only on bending the head forward/straining.  
5. The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when a clear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/paper towel.
6. Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluid accumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing, cough, and cold for the past few days. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It can develop secondary to infection in adenoids
It presents as a midline bulge
Tracheostomy maybe required in some cases

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high fever, noisy breathing, cough, cold, soft tissue swelling, and the widening of prevertebral shadow on the lateral view of the neck X-ray in a 2-year-old child suggests a likely diagnosis of acute retropharyngeal abscess. It presents as a bulge on one side of the midline and not as a midline bulge, due to the raphe that divides the retropharyngeal space.

An acute retropharyngeal abscess usually occurs in children below 3 years of age due to the infections of adenoids(Option A) or tonsils causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes which leads to the formation of an abscess. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is rare and usually secondary to trauma. 

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis(Option D) (extended stiff neck), and swelling on one side of the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The extent of the abscess can be visualized on a contrast-enhanced CT scan. 

Treatment is usually by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics but tracheostomy(Option C) may be required in cases of large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal edema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on the lateral view of the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis?

choices.text: It is caused by human papillomavirus types 16 and 18
It predominantly affects the subglottic region of the larynx
Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change

questions.solution:
Juvenile papillomatosis is characterized by papillomas that frequently recur (Option D), requiring multiple interventions to manage their benign growth. Despite their tendency to recur, these papillomas rarely undergo malignant transformation (Option D).

Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children, caused by human papilloma DNA virus types 6 and 11. (Option A)

It typically affects the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can extend to the subglottic area, trachea, and bronchi. (Option B) Symptoms often present between the ages of 3 and 5 years and include hoarseness, aphonia, and respiratory distress, sometimes leading to stridor. 

Diagnosis involves flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy followed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy for confirmation. Treatment primarily consists of micro laryngoscopy with CO2 laser excision to preserve vocal function and maintain a patent airway. (Option C)

Despite treatment efforts, papillomas frequently recur, necessitating repeated interventions. However, these growths seldom progress to malignancy, offering a favorable prognosis in terms of cancer risk.

questions.text: The sequence of events that result in a peritonsillar abscess are:

choices.text: Peritonsillitis --> Capsular breach --> Intratonsillar abscess --> Crypta magna infection --> Peritonsillar abscess
Crypta magna infection --> Intratonsillar abscess --> Capsular breach --> Peritonsillitis --> Peritonsillar abscess
Crypta magna infection --> Intratonsillar abscess --> Peritonsillitis --> Capsular breach --> Peritonsillar abscess
Intratonsillar abscess --> Peritonsillitis --> Crypta magna infection --> Capsular breach --> Peritonsillar abscess

questions.solution:
The right sequence of events that result in a peritonsillar abscess is

Crypta Magna infection --> Intratonsillar abscess --> Capsular breach --> Peritonsillitis --> Peritonsillar abscess.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

 Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

 Complications of peritonsillar abscess are:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Septicaemia
  • Pneumonitis/ lung abscess
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery/ jugular vein

questions.text: The differential diagnosis of a child with biphasic stridor should include all except:
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it is not considered as part of the differential diagnosis for biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

questions.text: An ENT resident administers a submucosal injection of Teflon paste to one of his patients. Which of the following nasal conditions is he treating?
questions.solution:
Injection of submucosal Teflon paste is a treatment approach for atrophic rhinitis.

The nasal chambers are very wide in atrophic rhinitis, so the air currents dry up the secretions, leading to crusting. Thus, the narrowing of the nasal airway helps relieve the symptoms.

Young’s operation - Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. The nostrils are re-opened after at least 6 months. With this procedure, the mucosa may revert to normal, and crusting may reduce.

Modified Young’s operation - This procedure aims at partially closing the nostrils. The result is the same as Young’s operation.

Other options:

Option A - Vasomotor rhinitis: Treated with vidian neurectomy, i.e. sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the nose

Option C - Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation. It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved using intranasal corticosteroids.

Option D - Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It usually affects young adults in the third to fourth decade of life and risk factors include malnutrition, poor hygiene, and overcrowding. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic right-sided ear discharge for the last 1.5 months presented with complaints of deep-seated ear pain, severe retro-orbital pain, and diplopia. On examination, the following finding is seen on lateral gaze. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of persistent ear discharge, deep-seated ear ache, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia is suggestive of Gradenigo syndrome, seen in petrous apicitis or petrositis. It is due to the spread of infection from the middle ear and mastoid to the petrous part of the temporal bone.

In this case, there is a failure of abduction of the right eye on lateral gaze, which indicates paralysis of the right lateral rectus due to right abducent (cranial nerve VI) nerve palsy. 

Gradenigo syndrome consists of a triad :

  • Persistent ear discharge
  • Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain
  • VI nerve palsy

 Infection from the mastoid air cells reaches the petrous apex via two pathways:

1. Postero-superior tract: starts at the mastoid, and runs behind or above the bony labyrinth or through the arc of the superior semicircular canal to the petrous apex.

2. Antero-inferior tract: starts at the hypotympanum, and goes around the cochlea to reach the petrous apex.

Dorello's canal is a dural sheath at the petrous apex which gives space for the passage of the abducent nerve and hence this nerve is compressed by the epidural abscess formed at the apex in petrositis. Retro-orbital pain is due to the involvement of the trigeminal ganglion.

HRCT and MRI of temporal bone help in reaching the diagnosis. 

FLAIR image showing hyperintensity at the right petrous apex due to pus and edema, indicative of petrous apicitis.

Other options:

Option A: Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis will present as headache, picket-fence fever, edema over mastoid, tenderness along the jugular vein, fatigue, blurring of vision, and rarely seizures.

Option C. Coalescent mastoiditis will present with mastoid tenderness and deep-seated ear ache but other features like retro-orbital pain and lateral rectus palsy will be absent.

Option D: Brain abscess will present as headache, high-grade fever, focal neurological deficits, and seizures. MRI of the brain will show central hypodensity with peripheral rim enhancement. Diffusion-weighted image (DWI) will show diffusion restriction.

questions.text: A patient presents with persistent nasal congestion for the last four weeks. He has been using intranasal decongestants for the last three weeks which initially provided relief. However, his symptoms recurred after two weeks of treatment. What is the next step in management for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent symptoms of nasal congestion after initial improvement with intranasal decongestants is likely to have rhinitis medicamentosa. The next step in management for this condition is stopping the use of intranasal decongestants. 

Rhinitis medicamentosa is also known as rebound congestion. It occurs due to overuse of topical nasal decongestants which leads to inflammation of the nasal mucosa. It occurs when decongestants are used for more than 7-10 days. The exact etiology is not known. 

Patients usually present with severe nasal congestion and nasal mucosa swelling that has an erythematous and granular appearance. 

It is treated by discontinuing the decongestant. This may lead to an initial worsening of symptoms which can be relieved by using intranasal corticosteroids. Some may also prescribe short-course oral corticosteroids, oral antihistamines, and inferior turbinate steroid injections but are not frequently recommended.

questions.text: ​​A young boy presents with bilateral nasal obstruction after being hit in the face with a football. There is no deviation of the nasal bridge, no bony tenderness and an intra-nasal examination reveals the image below. What is the immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a recent history of facial trauma, presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and bilateral smooth, round swellings (as seen in the image), likely indicating a septal hematoma. The immediate management for this condition is incision and drainage

Immediate drainage of septal hematomas is crucial to avoid long-term complications such as saddle deformity, perforation, and nasal base widening. In children, untreated hematomas can lead to significant nasal and midfacial growth abnormalities. Early intervention also helps prevent bacterial infections and severe complications like abscesses, osteomyelitis, and meningitis.

A Septal hematoma refers to blood collection under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery (as in this patient), or spontaneous in bleeding disorders.

Patients usually present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, smooth, round swellings, soft and fluctuant on palpation, can be seen on either side of the septum.

Small hematomas can be aspirated with a wide-gauge needle. Larger hematomas require incision and drainage, sometimes with excision of a small piece of mucosa for better drainage. The nose is then packed on both sides to prevent reaccumulation and systemic antibiotics are administered to prevent abscess formation.

Other options: 

Option A: CT scans are indicated for severe trauma or when there is physical evidence of other facial fractures to assess the extent of bony injury. Physical examination is generally sufficient for diagnosing nasal trauma. Plain radiographs may be obtained but suffer from high false positives and don't alter management. 

Option C: Closed nasal reduction is indicated for simple injuries like isolated unilateral nasal bone fractures with medial displacement. This patient has no nasal deformity.

Option D: Ichthammol glycerine packing is used in the management of furuncle of the external canal as an antiseptic and to reduce swelling. It is not useful in the management of septal hematomas.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: Which of the following cancers presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom?
questions.solution:
Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis.

Supraglottic and subglottic growths are often silent. Hoarseness is a late symptom.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions of the oral cavity are considered premalignant?
  1. Granular Cell Myoblastoma
  2. Erythroplakia
  3. Pregnancy Granuloma
  4. Mucosal hyperpigmentation
  5. Pyogenic Granuloma
  6. Leukoplakia
questions.solution:
Erythroplakia, Leukoplakia, and Mucosal hyperpigmentation are considered premalignant lesions.

Leukoplakia is defined as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by the Epstein–Barr virus. Smoking, tobacco chewing, and alcohol consumption are linked etiological factors. The most common sites involved are buccal mucosa and oral commissures. Males are affected two to three times more often.

Erythroplakia is a red patch or plaque on the mucosal surface. The red color is due to decreased keratinization and as a result, the red vascular connective tissue of the submucosa shines through. The most common sites are lower alveolar mucosa, gingivobuccal sulcus, and the floor of the mouth.  There is no sex predilection. Malignant potential is 17 times higher than in leukoplakia.

Melanosis and mucosal hyperpigmentation are benign pigmented lesions of the oral mucosa. They may transform into malignant melanomas. About one-fourth of mucosal melanomas may resemble benign lesions, and hence, biopsy may become mandatory.

Benign lesions of the oral cavity include:

  1. Papilloma
  2. Fibroma (Fibroepithelial polyp)
  3. Hemangioma
  4. Lymphangioma
  5. Torus
  6. Pyogenic granuloma
  7. Pregnancy granuloma
  8. Granular cell myoblastoma or Granular cell tumor
  9. Minor salivary gland neoplasms
  10. Solitary fibrous tumor
  11. Mucocele
  12. Ranula
  13. Dermoid

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. Which method of treatment is most efficacious for this patient?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings and can be managed by endoscopically clearing the fungus out of the sinus.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion. Treatment includes endoscopic surgical drainage along with drainage as well as ventilation. Steroids also must be administered pre and post-operatively.

Allergic fungal sinusitis occurs due to fungus induced inflammation of the sinuses and is prevalent in both immunocompetent as well as immunocompromised hosts.

Organisms that cause fungal sinusitis include :  

  • Aspergillus (m/c)
  • Mucormycosis
  • Candida
  • Penicillium species

Other options:

Option B: High recurrences and numerous accounts of treatment failures have displaced oral antifungals as a mode of treatment. 

Option C: Antihistamines and leukotriene antagonists are unlikely to treat this patient's fungal sinusitis but may reduce the associated symptoms.

Option D: Caldwell–Luc operation is a surgical procedure commonly used in otolaryngology to treat maxillary sinusitis. In this procedure, the antrum is accessed by making an incision in its anterior wall using a sublabial approach. The removal of all irreversible disorders is undertaken, followed by the establishment of a window connecting the antrum and inferior meatus. This invasive procedure is not necessary in the treatment of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient experienced a complete loss of vision following a functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic ethmoidal sinusitis. Which of the following air cells are in close anatomical proximity to the structure most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure most likely injured in this patient is the optic nerve and the Onodi cell is in close proximity to it.

Onodi cell is an anatomical variant, in which the posterior ethmoidal cells enlarge and extend into the sphenoid bone laterally and superior to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimetres from their anterior wall.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell or the sphenoethmoidal cell.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) which is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus or orbital floor above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A patient presents with paroxysmal sneezing, alternating nasal obstruction, and excessive watery nasal discharge that persists throughout the year. Anterior rhinoscopy shows congested nasal mucosa. All the tests for nasal allergy are negative and symptoms are refractory to medical management. What is the most likely diagnosis and definitive treatment?

choices.text: Non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome, Topical nasal steroids

questions.solution:
In the above-mentioned clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is vasomotor rhinitis, and the definitive treatment is Vidian neurectomy.

Initial treatment of vasomotor rhinitis includes antihistamines, oral nasal decongestants, and topical steroids. In case of failed medical treatment, Vidian neurectomy is done. Vidian neurectomy involves the sectioning of parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to nose.

Vasomotor rhinitis is characterized by symptoms that mimic allergic rhinitis but occur without any identifiable allergen, as evidenced by negative allergy tests. It is caused by abnormal regulation of the blood flow in the nasal mucosa, leading to alternating nasal obstruction, sneezing, and nasal discharge. The condition can be triggered by various stimuli such as temperature changes, humidity, strong odors, or stress.

Other options : 

Option B: Hypertrophic rhinitis, caused by recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and mucosal irritation, leads to thickening of the nasal tissues. The surgical treatment for this condition is turbinectomy.

Option C: Non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome (NARES) presents with perennial sneezing, watery discharge, nasal pruritis, and obstruction, with over 20% eosinophils in nasal smears. Topical nasal steroids are effective in treatment.

Option D: Atrophic rhinitis features a roomy nasal cavity, pale mucosa, dry crusts, and anosmia. Treatment includes warm saline irrigation, crust removal, and local antibiotics, with surgical management using a modified Young's operation to close the nostrils partially.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with local discomfort and a gritty sensation on palpation of the tonsils. Examination reveals the presence of stones composed of inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium lodged within the tonsillar crypts. What is the primary pathophysiological process responsible for their formation?

choices.text: Chronic inflammation of the tonsillar crypts
Viral infection causing epithelial changes in tonsils
Deposition of dietary calcium in tonsillar tissue

questions.solution:
Chronic tonsillitis leads to inflammation of the tonsillar crypts, causing accumulation of debris such as food particles, dead cells, and mucus. Inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium then deposit in these crypts, forming tonsilloliths or tonsil stones.

The stones composed of inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium found in the tonsillar crypts are known as tonsilloliths or tonsil stones. The primary pathophysiological process leading to their formation is:

  • Chronic inflammation of the tonsillar crypts: In chronic tonsillitis, inflammation of the tonsillar crypts occurs. These crypts can become blocked with debris, including food particles, dead cells, and mucus.
  • Retention of debris: The blocked tonsillar crypts retain debris, particularly inorganic salts such as calcium and magnesium.
  • Formation of stones: Over time, the accumulated debris solidifies and forms the tonsilloliths or tonsil stones.

Patients with tonsilloliths often present with symptoms such as local discomfort, a gritty sensation on palpation of the tonsils, and sometimes halitosis (bad breath) due to the presence of these stones. Diagnosis is usually made by palpation or visual inspection of the tonsils.

Treatment typically involves removal of the stones, either by manual extraction or, in cases of recurrent infections or severe symptoms, consideration of tonsillectomy.

Other options:

Option B: Autoimmune destruction of tonsillar tissue: Autoimmune disorders affecting the tonsils can lead to tissue damage but are not typically associated with the formation of tonsilloliths.

Option C: Viral infection causing epithelial changes in tonsils: While viral infections can cause inflammation of the tonsils, they do not directly lead to the formation of tonsilloliths composed of inorganic salts.

Option D: Deposition of dietary calcium in tonsillar tissue: Dietary calcium deposition is not a typical pathophysiological process leading to tonsillolith formation. Tonsilloliths primarily result from retaining inorganic salts in chronically inflamed tonsillar crypts.

questions.text: You are posted in the ENT department as an intern. The resident doctor shows you the X-ray of a patient with persistent nasal discharge and stuffy nose. The patient also complained of hard of hearing and frequent headaches, particularly over the occipital region. The resident doctor asks you the diagnosis and discusses the salient features of the condition seen in the x-ray. All of the following are true regarding this condition except?

choices.text: Arises from the median recess, representing attachment of notochord to endoderm.
Patient presents with persistent nasal discharge.
Located in the midline of posterior wall of the nasopharynx.

questions.solution:
The given image shows a thornwaldt cyst and it is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.

Thornwaldt cyst is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput. It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting.
  • Nasal obstruction due to swelling in the nasopharynx.
  • Obstruction to eustachian tube and serous otitis media.
  • Dull type of occipital headache.
  • Recurrent sore throat.
  • Low-grade fever.

Sometimes an abscess can form in the pharyngeal bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease). The abscess is treated with antibiotics.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker comes with complaints of change in voice. On examination, he is found to have dysphonia. The laryngoscopy finding during the phonation is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a male patient, who is a chronic smoker, with dysphonia, and laryngoscopy showing smooth, solitary pedunculated mass at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord are suggestive of a vocal polyp.

Vocal polyps are benign swellings arising from lamina propria of the vocal folds. They are common in men, predominately of age 30–50 years. Commonly associated with smoking and allergy. They are the most common cause of structural dysphonia. Clinical features include:

  • Dysphonia: Abnormal voice / sometimes double voice due to the difference in vibratory frequency of the two vocal cords.
  • Reduced vocal dynamic range.
  • Vocal cord straining to speak. 
  • In cases of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur. 

They are often solitary and on laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass. They arise from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. During respiration or phonation, they may flop up and down the glottis.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

Option A: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. Associated with certain occupations like teaching, singing, etc. They are small bilateral swellings (less than 3 mm in diameter) that develop on the free edge of the vocal fold at the maximal contact area (junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord).

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

 

Option A: Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

Option D: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma.

questions.text:
A patient after thyroid surgery develops dyspnoea and stridor without any change in voice. Which of the following nerve is injured?

B/L - Bilateral

U/L - Unilateral

choices.text: U/L superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerves are injured in this case.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (B/L abductor paralysis), all the intrinsic muscles of larynx (except cricothyroid) are paralyzed. Vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles. 

Classically, they present with airway compromise leading to dyspnoea and stridor. Voice quality is not affected as the paralysed cords assume their natural adducted position during phonation.

Other options

Option A: In bilateral superior laryngeal nerve paralysis, both the cricothyroid muscles are paralyzed with anaesthesia of upper larynx. Patients present with aspiration of food, cough, and choking fits with a weak and husky voice.

Option C: In unilateral superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis), all the muscles of larynx on one side are paralyzed. Vocal cord on the affected side will lie in cadaveric position. Glottic incompetence occurs as the healthy cord is unable to approximate the paralyzed cord.  They present with hoarseness of voice, aspiration of food, and ineffective cough.

Option D: In unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis, ipsilateral paralysis of all the intrinsic muscles (except cricothyroid) occurs. Vocal cord on the affected side lie in median or paramedian position. Patient maybe asymptomatic. Few may present with voice changes. However, aspiration and airway obstruction does not occur.

Unilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Few may have change in voice
  • No airway obstruction/ aspiration
Bilateral recurrent layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Airway obstruction (dyspnea, stridor)
  • No change in voice
Unilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Weak voice with inability to raise the pitch
  • Anaesthesia of larynx on one side causing occasional aspiration
Bilateral superior layngeal nerve paralysis
  • Aspiration of food (cough, choking)
  • Weak and husky voice
Unilateral recurrent and superior layngeal nerve paralysis (complete paralysis)
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Aspiration of food
  • Ineffective cough

questions.text: The structure marked on the lateral wall of the nasopharynx is visualized at which of the following stages of diagnostic nasal endoscopy?
questions.solution:
The image shown is the endoscopic view of the lateral wall of the nasopharynx showing Fossa of Rosenmuller (yellow arrow). This structure is visualized during the first pass of diagnostic nasal endoscopy.

In diagnostic nasal endoscopy three passes are performed :

  • The first pass is the examination of the nasopharynx and inferior meatus.
  • The second pass is the examination of sphenoethmoidal recess, superior meatus, and openings of sphenoid sinus and posterior ethmoidal cells.
  • The third pass is the examination of the middle meatus in detail.

Important structures seen in the nasopharynx are :

  • Pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube
  • Torus tubarius- tubal elevation which is present behind the opening of the eustachian tube.
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller - A lateral pharyngeal recess that is present above and behind the torus tubarius. It is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma 
  • Adenoids or nasopharyngeal tonsil, which is present in the roof and posterior wall
  • Passavant's ridge

questions.text: A patient comes to the ENT OPD with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. She has occasionally experienced tinnitus as well. Further evaluation by tuning fork tests revealed conductive hearing loss. Her tympanogram is shown below. Which of the following is the likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a type C tympanogram with normal compliance and negative pressure. It is seen in case of retracted tympanic membrane. It occurs due to eustachian tube blockage.

Tympanogram: Results of tympanometry are plotted in form of a tympanogram with:

  • Compliance on the Y axis (ease of mobility of TM)
  • Middle ear pressure on the X axis (regulated by eustachian tube)
