questions.text: A 45-year-old obese patient presents with autophony. He says he can even hear the sounds of his breath and this gets exaggerated when he performs pranayama. He recently undertook a rapid weight loss program and lost 45 kgs over three months. The image below shows the procedure performed and the instrument used, for the management of his condition. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a clinical history suggestive of rapid weight loss, patient hearing his voice (autophony) and the symptom getting exaggerated while attempting to breathe after closing opposite nostril (as performed during Yoga) is seen in patulous eustachian tube/ overtly/ abnormally patent eustachian tube. 

The treatment of this condition includes eustachian tube catheterization as shown in the image. Image A and B are steps involved in the procedure while image C shows the eustachian tube catheter. It is actually a curved, metal cannula, measuring about 5 inches in length. Its tip is curved gently downwards. It is used to catheterize the Eustachian tube and is also used to remove foreign bodies in the nose. 

Patulous eustachian tube: In this condition, the eustachian tube is abnormally patent. The patient’s primary complaints are hearing his voice & breathing sounds, which is known as autophony. 

The most common cause is idiopathic. It is commonly seen after rapid weight loss. The Ostmann fat pads are located inferomedial to the eustachian tubes and are important in the normal closure of the Eustachian tube, preventing transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear. Acute and significant loss of weight leading to loss of adipocytes in the Ostmann fat pad can lead to tubal dysfunction.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. Long-standing cases or specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Other options:

Option A: Tubal blockage: Can be acute or chronic. It can be reversed physiologically or by yawning or Valsalva maneuver. Symptoms include those associated with the development of negative pressure in the middle ear cavity, with sequelae being a collection of fluid and infection to hemorrhage. Other symptoms include otalgia, hearing loss, popping sensations, rarely vertigo. It is treated by relieving the obstruction, treating the cause like infection or inflammation, and preventing or averting infection by antibiotic supplementation.

Options B and D: Retracted eustachian tube/atelectasis of the tubes could be due to obstruction at any path between the eustachian tube and attic. Retraction pockets could be formed which if left untreated can lead to sclerotic changes or atelectasis. Management includes surgical clearing of pockets and the establishment of ventilation. Antibiotic supplementation is a must to avoid middle ear infections.

questions.solution:
Hidden areas of the larynx are infrahyoid epiglottis, anterior commissure, subglottis, and ventricle.

Direct Laryngoscopy is done during the workup of patients with laryngeal ca to see the hidden areas of the larynx and to determine the extent of disease. Hidden areas may not be clearly seen by laryngeal mirror examination making direct laryngoscopy essential.

Indirect laryngoscopy is done using a laryngeal mirror, which appears as below:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with difficulty swallowing, excessive tiredness, and loss of weight over the last few months. After further blood investigations and imaging, a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome was made. Which of the following findings is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
An esophageal web is likely to be seen in a patient with Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome. It is typically seen in women over 40 years of age. It includes the following features:

  • Dysphagia 
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Glossitis
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Koilonychia
  • Achlorhydria

The esophageal webs refer to esophageal constrictions caused by an atrophic mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen formed due to subepithelial fibrosis. They are usually seen in the cervical esophagus near post cricoid region.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a known risk factor for post-cricoid hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma.  

Other options-

Option A:  Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of peristalsis in the body of the esophagus and high resting pressure in the lower esophagus sphincter (LES). The LES does not relax when the patient swallows. This leads to dysphagia more to liquids than solids and regurgitation of food at night. A barium swallow will reveal a dilated esophagus with narrowed rat tail lower end called bird beak appearance. The barium swallow findings are seen in the image below. 

Option B: Diffuse esophageal spasm is a motility disorder of the esophagus. It is seen as a corkscrew appearance on a barium swallow. Esophageal manometry will show normal relaxation of the sphincter on swallowing. A barium swallow image of diffuse esophageal spasm is shown below-

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma is a common benign tumor of the esophagus. On a barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium. A barium study with the classic semilunar filling defect in esophageal leiomyoma is shown below-

questions.text: All of the following are true about Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs) except:

choices.text: OAEs are produced by the outer hair cells
OAEs can be used as a screening test for neonates
OAEs are absent in cochlear lesions
OAEs disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology

questions.solution:
OAEs do not disappear in VIIIth nerve pathology because they are produced by the outer hair cells of the cochlea and are not directly dependent on the auditory nerve.

Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are sounds generated by the activity of outer hair cells in a normal cochlea. These sounds can be recorded using a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal. OAEs are useful in evaluating cochlear function, particularly in newborn hearing screenings, as they are present when outer hair cells are healthy and absent when there is damage to the cochlea.

OAEs are divided into spontaneous and evoked types. Spontaneous OAEs occur without external stimulation, whereas evoked OAEs require an acoustic stimulus. Different methods exist to elicit evoked OAEs, such as transient evoked OAEs (TEOAEs) and distortion product OAEs (DPOAEs). 

OAEs are crucial in diagnosing hearing loss in various populations, including neonates and uncooperative patients. They help distinguish between cochlear and retro-cochlear pathology, as OAEs are absent in cochlear lesions but remain present in VIIIth nerve pathologies such as auditory neuropathy. This makes them a reliable tool for assessing the integrity of outer hair cells independent of neural function.

Other Options:

Option A: OAEs are generated by the motility of outer hair cells, reflecting the active process in the cochlea that amplifies sound.

Option B: OAEs are commonly used to screen hearing in neonates because the test is quick, non-invasive, and can be performed even when the infant is asleep.

Option C: OAEs are absent in cases of cochlear damage, such as sensorineural hearing loss caused by ototoxic drugs or noise exposure, as these conditions impair outer hair cell function.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complete obstruction of her right nostril with a woody hard swelling of her nose as shown in the image. She gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation before the swelling appeared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting before the development a woody hard swelling in the nose is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose. (image given below)

 

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. 

Histology shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Image below shows

  • Mikulicz cells - large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli
  • Russell bodies - homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells. (noted by arrows in the image)

 

The slide given below shows Russell bodies.

 

Treatment of rhinoscleroma:

  1. Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) for a period of 4 to 6 weeks.
  2. Steroids to reduce fibrosis.
  3. Surgical intervention to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.
  4. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative. 

Other options

Option A: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as pinkish, lobulated swelling over the tip of the nose. It is associated with acne rosacea.

 

 

Option B: Atrophic rhinitis or ozaena causes atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It presents with foul smelling nasal discharge with greenish or greyish black dry crusts but doesn’t cause woody nose.

 

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by the fungus Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

The image below shows a polypoidal mass of rhinosporidiosis.

 

Image below - Histopathology of rhinosporidiosis showing several sporangia, oval, or round in shape with a chitinous wall and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its wall.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.
